Violation_Type: Refugee claim based on lack of well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Sri Lanka due to Tamil ethnicity; Board found no credible evidence linking fear to race or political opinion; incidents involved authorities and post-war extortion unrelated to Convention grounds
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, linkage of evidence to Convention grounds
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, encounters with authorities, context of post-war Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence connecting experiences to race or political opinion
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's fear not credible or insufficiently linked to protected grounds
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the denial and granting of refugee protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Section 96
Decision_Rationale: No evidence established a link between the applicant's experiences and persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or social group; incidents were attributed to general law enforcement or criminal activity
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB), Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's decision denying refugee status due to lack of credible evidence and adequate state protection
Crimes.Governing_Law: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' testimony found inconsistent (e.g., number of cars owned, partial payment to FARC)
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of corroborating documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96, 97, and subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC in Colombia due to extortion and violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility and adequacy of state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None explicitly stated; inconsistencies undermined overall credibility
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presumption of state protection not rebutted
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in supporting claims for refugee status

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual claiming victimization by armed group
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Threats and demands by an illegal armed organization
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not applicable to applicant; attributed to FARC
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (alleged assault and threats by insurgent group)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as not credible due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personal safety risk from non-state actor
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted threat based on alleged extortion
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on alleged refusal to fully comply with extortion demand
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Found lacking due to implausible details
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted due to inconsistencies in narrative
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Pattern of threats and extortion preceding attempted abduction
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Availability of state protection mechanisms in Colombia
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Attributed to FARC as ongoing armed insurgency
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (threat of unlawful detention and harm)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Deemed not well-founded due to credibility issues
Crimes.Risk_Type: Risk of arbitrary deprivation of liberty
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted threat linked to extortion campaign
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on prior interactions and payments
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible by RPD
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of threats and fear of violence to extract payments
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of state institutions capable of providing protection
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of criminal behavior by FARC documented
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (coercion backed by threat of violence)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Present but deemed manageable through state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Ongoing coercive demands from non-state armed group
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, repeated demands directed at applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Partially supported by general country conditions, but individual claim lacked credibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined by inconsistencies in testimony
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Complicity in war crimes through personal and knowing participation or shared common purpose
Legal_Framework: UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Institutional_Action: Immigration and Refugee Board decision reviewed
Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
State_Protection_Assessment: Applicant did not disengage from Navy despite opportunities
Risk_Factor: Senior position in Sri Lankan Navy
Credibility: Supported by documentary evidence of systemic human rights abuses

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Complicity in crimes against humanity through personal and knowing participation or shared common purpose
Legal_Framework: UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Institutional_Action: Immigration and Refugee Board decision reviewed
Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
State_Protection_Assessment: Applicant remained in Navy despite knowledge of atrocities
Risk_Factor: Senior officer with long service in Sri Lankan Navy
Credibility: Supported by evidence of systemic abuses

Application_Facts: Applicant faced alleged threats from Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidence_Used: Threats by Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Generalized risks rather than Convention grounds, inconsistent evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues found by the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities, more than a mere possibility of persecution or torture
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was reasonable based on credibility concerns and lack of evidence linking threats to Convention grounds

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the panel erred in analyzing under section 97 instead of 96, and in finding an internal flight alternative
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on reasonableness of conclusions
Legal_Provision: Section 97 IRPA (person in need of protection)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged persecution due to ethnicity and past incidents
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of internal flight alternative in Colombo
Crimes.Application_Error: Misapplication of section 97 instead of section 96 alleged
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard for country condition changes and internal flight alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found by court; all evidence considered
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Applicant not recognized as a refugee or person in need of protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Arrest without charge by Sri Lanka Army
Crimes.Violation_Type: Claim of persecution based on arbitrary arrest and extortion
Crimes.Application_Facts: Multiple arrests by SLA, release upon payment of bribes
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Applicant left Sri Lanka safely, indicating ability to avoid harm
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – issue focused on credibility and risk nexus
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of section 97 instead of section 96 for analysis
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether Canadian tribunal had proper jurisdictional basis
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to establish nexus between arrests and protected grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially accepted but insufficient to prove persecution
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee or person in need of protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risks attributed to criminal extortion, not persecution on protected grounds

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on past torture
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether there is a well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Credible past events but no ongoing state interest post-war
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate ongoing risk
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Past events accepted, but future risk not established
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Risk must be personalized and linked to protected grounds
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Post-civil war conditions, ability to relocate to Colombo
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State interest diminished after end of civil war
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 96 and 97 IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on systemic targeting of Tamils
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Ethnicity, membership in particular social group
Crimes.Legal_Framework: UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Not recognized as refugee or protected person
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Available in Colombo outside conflict zones
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Extortion and harassment by paramilitary groups
Crimes.Credibility: Accepted in part, but generalized risk not sufficient
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA Section 96 and 97
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate in internal flight alternative locations
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Criminal acts without clear nexus to persecution
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Pillaiyan group and Sri Lanka Army

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on extortion and harassment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether extortion constitutes persecution under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Extortion occurred but for financial gain, not protected grounds
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show nexus to protected ground
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Events accepted as true but lack required legal nexus
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Criminal acts without nexus to race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or social group do not constitute persecution
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Ethnicity, membership in particular social group
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of extortion, ability to leave area, safety in Colombo
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Acts were criminal, not state-sponsored persecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA Section 96 and 97

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to analyze subjective fear of persecution before assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted by tribunal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged threats from FARC in Ecuador
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 72 et seq. of IRPA
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Subjective fear must precede state protection analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Credibility and plausibility of applicant's fear
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Subjective fear analysis required prior to state protection evaluation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to assess subjective fear before determining state protection availability
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Lack of credibility analysis regarding fear of persecution
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish subjective fear
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Threats from FARC not assessed for credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subjective fear must be evaluated before state protection
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative tribunal decision under review
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 72 et seq. IRPA

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in the U.S. and illegal entry into Canada
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Ecuador, overstayed U.S. visa, entered Canada illegally
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration status in both U.S. and Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential failure to disclose prior unlawful stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Sequence of refugee claim analysis under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Alleged FARC threats and flight path
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No credibility assessment of applicant's fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not performed by Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness due to omitted fear analysis
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to seek asylum in the United States
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to pursue available asylum protection in a safe third country
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Safe Third Country Agreement between Canada and the U.S.
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in U.S. illegally after fleeing Ecuador, did not apply for asylum there
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential omission or justification of failure to claim asylum in U.S.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to assess subjective fear before evaluating state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of state protection analysis sequence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No analysis of credibility or plausibility of fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mandatory sequence: subjective fear before state protection

Violation_Type: Failure to establish nexus to Convention grounds
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution based on ethnicity (Indo-Guyanese) and wealth in Guyana
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by the Board
Evidence_Used: Claims of ethnic persecution, criminal targeting
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis linking criminal acts to ethnic identity
Legal_Standard_Applied: Nexus to a Convention ground: race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to adequately explain how the applicants' experiences connect to their protected grounds under the Convention; focused on crime without linking it to ethnicity

Governing_Law: Charter of Rights and Freedoms (procedural fairness)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of forced marriage and female genital mutilation (FGM) upon return to Mali
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant was outside country of origin seeking protection
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony leading to credibility concerns
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to apply Gender Guidelines in a gender-related claim
Credibility_Assessment: Negative – Board found applicant's story not credible
Decision_Outcome: Refugee protection claim denied by the Board
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed by Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a protected person under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law
Decision_Rationale: Despite error in not applying Gender Guidelines, overall decision supported by credible evidence and no breach of procedural fairness

Application_Facts: The Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed by the RPD and upheld by the RAD, prompting a judicial review.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD erred by applying a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent assessment.
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred back to a different RAD panel
Remedy_Sought: Independent reassessment by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: The RAD has equal expertise to the RPD in assessing documentary evidence and must conduct an independent assessment rather than reviewing for reasonableness.

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 24(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration; had negative refugee claim and PRRA decision
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant with pending applications
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Refugee and PRRA decisions, sponsorship application status
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear evidence of irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No reviewable error found in officer's assessment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Delay in enforcement of removal order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tri-partite test (serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public interest in enforcing removal orders outweighs individual circumstances

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 24(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to maintain legal status; submitted spousal sponsorship without approval
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Rejected refugee claimant with pending sponsorship
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of removal decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Negative refugee and PRRA decisions, sponsorship application details
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Speculative claims of harm without supporting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not substantiated with credible evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Tri-partite test for stay of removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public interest in prompt enforcement of immigration laws
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Federal Court

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Potential hardship upon return to Venezuela
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Low to moderate (assault charge mentioned but no conviction details)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as low in context of removal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to lack of corroboration
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – focus on immigration consequence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code of Canada, Section 265

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with court order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for stay of removal under tripartite test
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to meet tri-partite test
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: History of non-compliance with immigration obligations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Pending applications and fear of harm in home country
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Negative refugee determination, PRRA refusal, lack of travel fitness issues
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister opposed stay citing public interest
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 114 of IRPA (enforcement of removal)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-97
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection in Canada as a Christian fearing persecution in China; Member rejected claim due to perceived implausibilities and lack of religious knowledge
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide concrete reasons for credibility findings
Inadequate consideration of cultural context and regional legal variances
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to support implausibility findings
Misinterpretation of religious practices and Chinese law enforcement practices
Credibility_Assessment: Findings based on unsupported assumptions
Ignored regional variances in law enforcement and religious practice
Decision_Rationale: Errors in law and fact-finding, including failure to properly assess credibility and country conditions

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate lack of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 96 or 97
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by SSP in Pakistan due to religious affiliation; alleged insufficient state protection against sectarian violence
Residency_Compliance: Claimant was in Canada and seeking refugee status; residency status pending determination
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on Pakistan's efforts to control sectarian violence, including military and police presence and government initiatives
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to prove state inability to protect nationals in Pakistan
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant failed to demonstrate lack of state protection; credibility not explicitly challenged but burden of proof not met
Standard_of_Review: Patently unreasonable standard applied to Board's findings
Decision_Rationale: State protection does not need to be perfect; Pakistan maintains functional military, police, and civil authority making serious efforts to protect citizens despite challenges with sectarian violence

Application_Facts: ADIR seeks to amend pleadings arguing subclasses are patentably distinct; Schering and Hoechst oppose, citing irrelevance and lack of detrimental reliance.
Procedural_Issue: Motion to amend pleadings
Admissibility of file record evidence
Decision_Outcome: Motion to amend pleadings is allowed
Outcome: Amended pleadings permitted to proceed to trial
Remedy_Sought: Inclusion of argument on patentable distinctness of subclasses
Legal_Standard_Applied: Amendments should only be denied in plain and obvious cases
Decision_Rationale: Amendment does not prejudice other parties and raises valid issues for trial

Application_Facts: Paul failed to present new evidence or show irreparable harm; Grenada was actively addressing domestic violence; her H&C application could proceed post-removal
Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal heard in Federal Court
Remedy_Sought: Prevent deportation to Grenada due to risk from domestic violence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test for stay of removal: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: No serious issue or irreparable harm shown; state protection available in Grenada; H&C application can continue post-removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Senior Official in Regime with Human Rights Violations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Male applicant served as Lieutenant Colonel (rank 6 of 17) in the Iraqi army under Saddam Hussein's regime; Officer used military hierarchy charts and consulted War Crimes Unit to assess seniority.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of duty of fairness during assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants were given opportunity to respond; no deficiency noted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Position fell within top half of military hierarchy; decision was reasonable and transparent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Violation of human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with regime committing human rights violations
Crimes.Outcome: No violation found by reviewing body; application dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Male applicant’s role as senior military official in Saddam Hussein’s regime
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights standards
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Assessment by Immigration Officer with input from War Crimes Unit
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Regime engaged in human rights violations
Crimes.Credibility: Applicants had opportunity to respond; credibility not directly challenged
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 35(1)(b), Regulation s. 16(e)
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed inadequate due to nature of regime

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa after failed refugee claim; sought H&C exemption to remain with Canadian wife and stepchildren
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence on establishment, risk, family ties, and stepchildren's best interests
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited evidence provided regarding integration and children's best interests
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds to remain in Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of H&C rejection and authorization to stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably assessed establishment, risk, and family impact based on available evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Rejection of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable error in H&C decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No finding of misrepresentation; credibility not central
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA related to H&C considerations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to consider new risk evidence and children's best interests
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Alleged but not substantiated – court found officer considered relevant factors

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Rejection of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable error in H&C decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding; lack of sufficient evidence from applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal statements, risk documentation, family relationship details
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions related to H&C discretion under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to properly assess hardship, risk, and children's interests
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Reasonableness of decision given limited evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged pre-judgment and insufficient consideration of factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Alleged, but court found officer addressed key issues
Crimes.Application_Factor: Establishment in Canada, personal risk, family impact

Violation_Type: Asylum claim based on lack of credibility, availability of state protection, and internal flight alternative
Application_Facts: Applicant alleged persecution by a drug trafficker in Mexico but failed to provide corroborative evidence or exhaust local remedies
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with residency or entry regulations due to failed asylum claim
Misrepresentation_Element: Possible misrepresentation due to contradictions in testimony
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide sufficient corroboration and failure to exhaust local remedies
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony found inconsistent and not credible
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal found contradictions in testimony and existence of safe internal flight alternative in Mexico; decision was reasonable

Application_Facts: Applicant Li Zhang accumulated 922 days of residence in Canada within four years before application, falling short of the required 1095 days; residence established on October 2, 2002
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Record of residence days, application date, residency establishment date
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documented days of physical residence
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship or re-evaluation of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative and qualitative residency test under section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the law; no reviewable error found as applicant did not meet minimum 1095-day requirement

Application_Facts: Mr. Abdulghafoor's citizenship application was approved by a citizenship judge despite limited evidence of physical presence in Canada; the Minister challenged the decision based on insufficient residency evidence.
Residency_Compliance: Discrepancies in physical presence evidence were not significant enough to undermine the reasonableness of the decision.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed the reasonableness of the citizenship judge's decision.
Evidence_Used: Landlord letters, tax assessments, border records, credibility findings
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited evidence of physical presence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: The citizenship judge found Mr. Abdulghafoor credible despite some discrepancies.
Decision_Outcome: The citizenship judge's decision to grant citizenship was upheld.
Outcome: The court dismissed the Minister's application for judicial review.
Relief_Sought: The Minister sought to overturn the citizenship judge's decision.
Decision_Rationale: The decision was justified, transparent, and intelligible based on the evidence and credibility assessment.

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed the Board erred by proceeding without adjourning for counsel, failing to consider state protection, and making unreasonable factual findings.
Procedural_Issue: No adjournment requested
Alleged lack of procedural fairness
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility findings were reasonable
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Immigration and Refugee Board
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error exists; no adjournment was requested, state protection evidence was insufficient, and credibility findings were reasonable.

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant is an Indian citizen and if procedural fairness was breached
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to present evidence despite opportunity
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Fraudulent passport, legal precedents on citizenship by birth
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA - Citizenship acquisition must be beyond applicant's control
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Statelessness and risk of persecution in China
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant entitled to Indian citizenship by birth
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose true citizenship status
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; applicant had opportunity but did not provide evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires opportunity to present evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent travel document upon entry
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for facts, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Entered with a fraudulent Indian passport

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making a false representation to obtain refugee status
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship status and credibility in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in determining Indian citizenship and breached fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of statelessness not substantiated; failure to pursue citizenship
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of citizenship documents, identity document from India
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Control test under IRPA for citizenship acquisition
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Statelessness and fear of persecution in China
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Citizenship in India was accessible and within applicant’s control
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for factual errors, correctness for procedural issues
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No attempt made to obtain Indian citizenship despite entitlement
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Refugee protection denied if citizenship can be obtained in a safe country
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Reliance on false claim of statelessness

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Duty to disclose relevant personal circumstances
Crimes.Application_Facts: Born in India, holds Indian identity document, claims statelessness
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant with Canadian immigration process until appeal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of entitlement to Indian citizenship
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Opportunity provided but no action taken to clarify status
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of RAD over RPD decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Indian citizenship law, possession of Indian ID document
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No attempt to acquire formal citizenship documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted due to lack of effort to confirm or deny citizenship
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Control test: ability to acquire/enforce citizenship rights
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant must pursue local remedies before claiming refugee status

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to pursue available legal remedies in home country
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Requirement to seek protection in country of nationality
Crimes.Application_Facts: Born in India, legally entitled to citizenship, did not apply
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada during proceedings
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied denial of citizenship access despite legal entitlement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to raise counter-evidence at RPD stage
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of RAD review under subsection 72(1) IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Indian citizenship law, lack of application for citizenship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of attempts to claim citizenship or denial thereof
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unsubstantiated claims against India undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Control test for availability of local remedies
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Protection must be sought in country where citizenship is available

Credibility_Assessment: efforts deemed insufficient by RPD

Risk_Assessment: risk of persecution or danger upon return
Credibility_Assessment: failure to fully pursue state protection undermined claim

Application_Facts: claim of past persecution and inadequate state protection in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: adequacy of efforts to seek state protection
Evidence_Used: documentary evidence on state protection in Mexico
Evidentiary_Deficiency: did not report all incidents to police
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found efforts insufficient
Decision_Rationale: adequate state protection exists in Mexico despite corruption

Risk_Assessment: risk to life and personal security upon return
Credibility_Assessment: delay and lack of reporting weakened claim

Aggravating_Factors: occurred in context of broader violence
Risk_Assessment: risk of further victimization upon return
Evidence_Credibility: credible but insufficient engagement with authorities
Credibility_Assessment: efforts to access protection deemed inadequate

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Bangladesh due to alleged persecution by the Awami League for involvement with the Bangladesh Nationalist Party.
Discrepancies noted between testimony and Basis of Claim Form.
Applicants did not seek asylum in the U.S. despite opportunity.
Claimant_Status: Principal Applicant and family claiming refugee protection
Residency_Compliance: Complied with Canadian immigration procedures upon entry
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider explanations for discrepancies
Overreliance on failure to claim asylum in the U.S.
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence of political affiliation and threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD discounted documentary evidence without sufficient justification
Lack of proper explanation for discrediting applicant's account
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant evasive and inconsistent
Federal Court found credibility assessment unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on credibility findings
Outcome: Referred back to new RPD panel
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on grounds of race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: RPD's credibility analysis was unreasonable
Explanations provided by applicants were ignored
Failure to claim asylum in the U.S. was given undue weight

Violation_Type: Failure to rebut presumption of adequate state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants faced threats from FARC after refusing to publish a book; reported threats to authorities but felt unprotected; Colombia struggles to protect targeted individuals despite efforts against FARC
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to consider specific risks faced by applicants
Evidence_Used: Evidence of threats from FARC, reports to authorities, country condition evidence on Colombia's protection capacity
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to adequately assess specific risks
Outcome: Application allowed, decision set aside, case remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Convention refugee and person in need of protection under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Board did not adequately assess the specific risks faced by the applicants despite evidence of threats and inadequate state protection

Application_Facts: Visa officer reviewed new arguments and reaffirmed refusal in April 20, 1994 letter; applicant filed judicial review within 30 days of that letter
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking judicial review of visa refusal
Procedural_Issue: Timeliness of judicial review application
Whether April 20 letter constitutes a new decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether court has jurisdiction based on timing of decision
Decision_Outcome: April 20, 1994 letter is a valid decision
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; respondent's motion dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Review of both February 8 and April 20 decisions
Legal_Standard_Applied: 30-day deadline for judicial review under s. 18.1
Decision_Rationale: April 20 letter constituted a new decision as it reviewed new arguments and reaffirmed refusal

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status based on political persecution
Procedural_Issue: Board used conflicting standards ('balance of probabilities' and 'serious possibility') in decision-making
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Unclear application of the correct legal test
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by the Board
Outcome: Board's decision quashed, new hearing ordered
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision, new hearing
Standard_of_Review: Correct legal test under section 96 of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in applying the correct legal test for determining refugee status

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nguyen, a Vietnamese citizen, had a nine-month absence from his Vietnamese business and expressed intent to stay in Canada with his children.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for a work permit
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to prove compliance with temporary residency requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed reasonableness of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Applicant's ties to Vietnam, duration of absence from business, statements about family in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of strong evidence showing intent to return to Vietnam
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen's claim of intent to return was weakened by prolonged absence and desire to remain with children
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and grant work permit
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Proof of intention to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Tribunal reasonably concluded Nguyen did not prove he would leave Canada after his authorized stay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer acted reasonably in refusing the work permit due to insufficient proof of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Regulation 200(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; work permit not issued
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen lacked strong ties to Vietnam and expressed desire to stay in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Business ownership in Vietnam, duration of absence, familial connections in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulation 200(1)(b) – Requirement to prove intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant failed to meet regulatory requirement to demonstrate intent to depart Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Weak ties to home country and expressed intent to remain in Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of applicant’s intent based on ties to home country
Crimes.Application_Factor: Duration of absence from Vietnamese business and presence of children in Canada
Crimes.Authority: Canadian Visa Office, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) Grounds Application Refusal
Legal_Issue: Sufficiency of reasons for refusal of H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Consideration of applicant's establishment in Canada, best interests of children, risk upon return to Nigeria
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant to demonstrate unusual hardship or compelling circumstances
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions must be reasonable, transparent, and intelligible
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient reasons provided by immigration officer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Children's interests, risk in country of origin, establishment in Canada
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law, IRPA, Federal Court Rules
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer considered both positive and negative factors
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal circumstances, country condition reports

Legal_Issue: Can the Board determine a foreign national is not a spouse without assessing marriage genuineness?

Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies and lack of evidence for common interests
Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence for common interests
Basis_of_Claim: Marriage was for immigration purposes or not genuine
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed, no question certified for appeal

Mitigating_Factors: Diminished influence of Atyanski after prosecution

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicants failed to meet their burden of proving identity with acceptable documentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.106, Refugee Protection Division Rules s.7
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, no declaratory relief granted
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Secondary evidence and witness testimonies lacked credibility

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Forensic test results were inconclusive or raised doubts

Crimes.Application_Factor: Submission of documents with questionable authenticity
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspected alterations or lack of security features in submitted documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicants failed to prove their identities for refugee status

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to establish identity under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with identity verification requirements

Crimes.Residency_Compliance: N/A - issue pertains to admissibility, not residency status

Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: N/A - within jurisdiction of Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No reliable primary or secondary documents establishing identity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Witnesses lacked credibility; documents were questionable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected due to lack of identity proof
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no declaratory relief granted
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable justification for absence of identity documents
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicants failed to provide verifiable identity documents or plausible explanation
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Outcome: RPD's decision found unreasonable and quashed

Crimes.Application_Error: RPD failed to adequately assess operational adequacy despite available evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court

Crimes.Application_Factor: Domestic violence, attempts to seek protection, lack of police response

Dispute_Type: Allegation of discriminatory remarks by immigration officers
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in law by dismissing a discrimination complaint due to lack of evidence and credibility issues
Governing_Law: s. 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting evidence, lack of corroboration, prior investigations found no misconduct
Burden_of_Proof: On the complainant to establish credible evidence of discrimination
Credibility_Factor: Credibility issues with the complainant's allegations
Legal_Rule: Commission may dismiss a complaint if an inquiry is not warranted based on all circumstances
Outcome_on_Merits: No sufficient evidence to proceed; complaint dismissed on merits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Complainant's testimony, lack of supporting witnesses, prior investigation findings
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but prior investigations concluded no misconduct
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission's dismissal decision
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose negative assessment to visa applicant

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of adverse evidence

Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached due to procedural breach
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Directed applicant to use Access to Information request
Crimes.Outcome: Disclosure ordered, decision quashed, costs awarded
